greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 1, a(2) = 2, a(3) = 3; for n >3 a(n) = smallest number not already used such that gcd(a(n), a(n-1)) >= 3.
comment: A permutation of the natural numbers.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
J. C. Lagarias, E. M. Rains and N. J. A. Sloane, The EKG sequence, arXiv:math/0204011 [math.NT], 2002; Exper. Math. 11 (2002), 437-446.
J. C. Lagarias, E. M. Rains and N. J. A. Sloane, Problem 10927, Amer. Math. Monthly, 109 (2002), 202; The EKG Sequence: 10927, 111 (No. 2, 2004), 167-168.
Index entries for sequences related to EKG sequence
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
mathematica: a[n_ /; n <= 3] := n; a[n_] := a[n] = For[aa = Array[a, n-1] // Sort; k = If[n == 4, 4, Complement[Range[aa // Last], aa] // First]; aa = Drop[aa, k-1], True, k++, If[FreeQ[aa, k], If[GCD[k, a[n-1]] >= 3, Return[k]]]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 28 2015 *)
program: f x us = x' : f x' (delete x' us) where
x' = head [u | u <- us, gcd u x > 2]
xref: Cf. A064413. A064956 gives inverse permutation.
results.author: Jonathan Ayres (Jonathan.ayres(AT)btinternet.com), Sep 30 2001
